sub_title: PhD Researcher Creativity & Mental Illness & Lecturer The Mad Genius Debate at VUmc & Lecturer at Utrecht University
summary:
research interests include : 
Vincent van Gogh and the art of his time | 
Art & Madness / Creativity & Mental Illness | History of Mad Genius
Printmaking & Politics / Anarchism

projects.title: creating and lecturing VU honours course The Mad Genius Debate
projects.description:
Since the nineteenth century a relationship is established between creativity and mental illness: either a disturbed mind generates exceptional creative achievements or creativity leads to mental problems. This idea is not only deeply rooted in the popular view, but also sustained by academic research, especially done by psychiatrists and psychologists. The many examples of artists, writers and other creative figures who suffered from mental problems and chose an untimely death further strengthen this image of the mad genius. However, how valid is this notion?
We will examine the history of the mad genius and the current debate, looking at the different perspectives, of the psychiatrist and of the artist. Is the artist an enlightened mind – and is his/her suffering inevitable – or is he/she a victim, made ill or pathologized by society? Or is it an image, made by an artist (or critic, agent, dealer etc.) aware of his/her reputation?

projects.title: Organisation of the symposium The Artwork Exposed: Politics and the Arts, 1850-1914
projects.description:
A two day conference on the relationship between art and politics in the late nineteenth century, held at the Van Gogh Museum and Rijksmuseum, Amsterdam, 17-18 April 2014.
I gave the lecture "L’Art pour l’art or L’Art pour tous? The Artist, the Anarchist in Les Temps nouveaux, 1896-1903".
For a short report (in Dutch) on the symposium, see http://www.historici.nl/nieuws/verslag-statuomanie-opportunisme-en-idealen-politieke-dimensies-van-kunst-de-negentiende-eeuw

authors.headline: PhD Researcher Creativity & Mental Illness & Lecturer The Mad Genius Debate at VUmc & Lecturer at Utrecht University

profile_positions.description:
Creating the Mad Genius: A History of the Relation Between Mental Illness and Creativity

Since the nineteenth century a relationship is established between creativity and mental illness: either a disturbed mind generates exceptional creative achievements or creativity leads to mental problems. This idea is not only deeply rooted in the popular view, but also sustained by academic research, especially done by psychiatrists and psychologists. The many examples of artists, writers and other creative figures who suffered from mental problems and chose an untimely death further strengthen this (romantic) image of the mad genius. Sceptic scholars have criticized the relationship’s advocates for their insufficient evidence and weak arguments. Yet, despite their valid critical notes, the opponents’ denial of a relationship between the artist’s creativity and his mental illness is too radical, because it ignores the history of this question and the long list of famous examples. A dialogue between the two camps rarely takes place; the persistent belief versus simple denial is probably what prevents a productive exchange.
profile_positions.title: PhD Researcher Creativity and Mental Illness & Lecturer The Mad Genius Debate
